answers: Valentine’s Day [accept: St. Valentine’s Day Massacre]
parts: Name this infamous Chicago gangster nicknamed “Scarface," who was eventually arrested on tax evasion charges in 1931.
On the morning of this holiday, seven members of Bugs Moran’s North Side Gang were gunned down by mobsters belonging to Capone’s Chicago Outfit in Lincoln Park Garage.

This other Italian mobster established the First Commission which created a ruling committee consisting of the Five Families and the Chicago Outfit. He was the first boss of the Genovese crime family.

answers: Said Mahran [accept either underlined portion] <Long Fiction, AK><ed. OC>
parts: Name this author of The Thief and the Dogs and a trilogy of novels including Palace Walk, Palace of Desire, and Sugar Street.
Mahfouz hails from this country, the setting of the aforementioned Cairo Trilogy.
This revolutionary protagonist of The Thief and the Dogs is heartbroken by his estrangement from his daughter Sana and unsuccessfully seeks revenge on his former wife Nabawiyya.

answers: infrared spectroscopy [or IR spectroscopy, accept spec in place of spectroscopy for either]
parts: Name this form of spectroscopy that is named for the part of the electromagnetic spectrum that has a wavelength just greater than that of visible light and has a frequency comparable to that at which molecules vibrate.
Because it has 12 atoms, this molecule has 30 normal modes of vibration. Its derivatives include toluene [["tol-you-ene”]] and aniline [["ann-uh-lean”]].

This complex region of the IR spectrum typically occurs from about 1500 to 500 inverse centimeters. It is unique for different compounds and is typically used to distinguish between similar compounds.
The canal was purchased by this Prime Minister, the first of Jewish descent and longtime rival of William Gladstone led the Conservative Party through much of the 1860’s and 1870’s
This man resigned as Prime Minister due to his mishandling of the Suez Crisis. This man previously resigned as Foreign Secretary to protest Neville Chamberlain’s policies of appeasement.
Eden was replaced by Harold Macmillan, who gave the “Winds of Change” speech this country’s parliament. A peoples in this country led by Cetshwayo defeated Britain at the Battle of Isandlwana.
Many plaques and figures made of this material sourced from Syrian elephants were discovered in the city of Nimrud, and contain carvings of sphinxes, lions, and serpents.
Two of these monuments made of limestone are decorated with bas-relief sculptures and commemorate Shalmaneser III and Ashurnasirpal I. They are four-sided columns capped by pyramids.

The Assyrians used alabaster gypsum to carve sculptures of these deities. They are depicted as winged bulls with human heads and are sculpted with five legs to provide the illusion of simultaneously walking and standing.

answers: Belgium <Current Events, AK and KLu><ed. AK and KLu>
parts: Name this movement that pushed for the independence of an autonomous community from an Iberian kingdom.
Protests for and against Catalan independence took place in this city, Catalonia’s largest and Spain’s second-largest. This city also hosted the 1992 Summer Olympics.

Carles Puigdemont, one of the foremost leaders of the Catalan independence movement, fled to this country. In 2016, terrorists attacked the Maelbeek metro station and the airport in the capital city of this country.
Name this art form that also includes Abramovic’s The Artist is Present, in which she sat silently in MoMA while viewers took turns sitting across from her.
Another example of performance art was Cut Piece, in which spectators were invited to cut the clothing off of this Japanese artist. This artist was also married to John Lennon.
Ono belonged to this group of avant-garde artists. This group was founded by George Maciunas [[“ma CHU nas”]] and also included the Korean video artist Nam June Paik.
Name this jubilant poem that exclaims “Be embraced, Millions!” and is set to music in Beethoven’s final symphony.
“Ode to Joy” is by this German poet who recounted the rivalry between brothers Franz and Karl Moor in his play The Robbers.
This other German Romantic poet recounted how “the boatman / Is seized by [a melody] with a savage woe” and is dragged to his death by a mermaid in “Die Lorelei.”

answers: Our Lady or the Virgin of Guadalupe
parts: Name this Mexican title for the Virgin Mary whose image is now enshrined in Mexico City.
Some speculate that the Virgin of Guadalupe was created from this process of combining different religious beliefs. This process often occurred in the Greco-Roman world with deities like Serapis.
The original image of the Virgin of Guadalupe featured a gold one of these objects that briefly disappeared in 1888. Roman soldiers fashioned one out of thorns to mock Christ’s claim to kingship.

answers: Los Angeles Dodgers [prompt on Los Angeles]
New York Yankees [prompt on New York]
Roy Campanella <Pop Culture/Mixed Academic, AK and CT><ed. KLu and AK>
parts: Name this National League West team who moved away from Brooklyn in 1958 under owner Walter O’Malley.

Scully holds the record for the youngest broadcaster of a World Series game for calling the 1953 World Series, during which the Dodgers lost to this team, whose 27 World Series titles is the most of all-time.

The Dodgers were led during the 1953 World Series by this catcher, 1953’s Most Valuable Player. This former Negro League star also won the 1951 and 1955 MVP awards before a 1958 car accident ended his career.

answers: Thomas Young [accept Young-Laplace equation or Young’s modulus]
contact angle [prompt on theta] <Physics, VS><ed. VS>
parts: Name this cohesive force that minimizes the surface area of a fluid. It appears to result in an elastic film lying on top of a fluid.
The capillary pressure due to surface tension can be calculated using an equation named for this scientist and Laplace. A quantity named for this scientist is equal to stress over strain.
The radius terms in the Young-Laplace equation can be defined in terms of this angle, which quantifies the hydrophobicity of a surface.

Name this class of Japanese warriors, key fighters during the Sengoku period, who adhered to the bushido code. Name some things about the social classes of the Sengoku, or Warring States, period in Japan.
Samurai were employed by these large landowners, whose landownings were reorganized into the han system by Hideyoshi.

The defeat of many daimyo at the Battle of Sekigahara led to the creation of this class, composed of samurai without employers. Tokugawa marched on Hideyoshi’s forces at Osaka after Hideyoshi began recruiting soldiers of this class.
Name this play centering around the pipe dreams of those inhabiting Harry Hope’s saloon. At the end of the play, the hardware salesman Hickey is arrested for murdering his wife Evelyn.
The Iceman Cometh was written by this American playwright of Long Day’s Journey Into Night.
O’Neill also wrote this play cycle in which Orin kills Captain Brant for having an affair with his mother Christine, prompting Christine to kill herself.

answers: income inequality [accept wealth inequality; prompt on inequality] <Social Science, AK><ed. JB>
parts: Name this condition, whose thermal part can be measured in miles per gallon and is known as fuel economy.
This Italian’s namesake “efficiency” states a condition in which a person can’t be better off without making someone else worse off.
In his formulation of the 80/20 principle, Pareto explored this economic phenomenon, which can be represented by a Gini coefficient.

answers: first partial derivative [or partial differentiation, do not accept “derivative” or “differentiation”]
sum [accept partial sum or summation] <Other Science, KLei><ed. KLei>
parts: Name this specific operation whose order is interchangeable according to Clairaut’s [["clare-owes”]] theorem.
Partial fraction decomposition can be used to simplify this operation, which is the inverse of differentiation according to the fundamental theorem of calculus.

The nth “partial” one of these things can be found by adding the first n terms of a sequence. In general, uppercase sigmas indicate calculating one of these things, which are formed from the addition of numbers.

answers: Chillon Castle [accept Château de Chillon, prompt on castle] <Long Fiction, AK><ed. OC>
parts: Name this American socialite, the love interest of Frederick Winterbourne. In the work in which she appears, she is ostracized for her relationship with Mr. Giovanelli and dies of Roman Fever.
Daisy Miller is a work by this American author of Portrait of a Lady and The Turn of the Screw.
In Daisy Miller, Winterbourne is shocked by Daisy’s insistence that he accompany her to this location. Lord Byron wrote a narrative poem about “The Prisoner of” this place.

answers: Hernando de Soto <European History, AK and JP><ed. AH>
parts: This man named one island in the modern day Bahamas San Salvador. This Genoese explorer departed from Spain in 1492 and is often given credit for being the first European to discover the Americas.

This Italian rejected Columbus’ conjecture that the West Indies was in Asia, instead claiming that it was part of a separate landmass. The Latin version of this man’s first name now lends its name to two continents.
This man completed the first documented crossing of the Mississippi River by a European. Francisco Pizarro sent this man to invite the Incan emperor Atahualpa to a meeting.

answers: Mars, the Bringer of War [prompt on but do not reveal The Planets]
parts: Name this first movement of a certain suite, which provided the inspiration for John Williams’ Star Wars soundtrack.
Mars is a movement from The Planets, a suite by this English composer who reworked “Fantasia on the Dargason” in his St. Paul’s Suite.
Holst was a major influence on this other English composer, who based his oratorio A Child of Our Time on the horrors of Kristallnacht.

answers: neurons [accept nerve cell, do not accept “neuroglia”]] <Biology, KLei><ed. VS>
parts: Name these cells. A hallmark of helminth infection is the elevated presence of these cells, which combat parasites.

In an H&E stain, hematoxylin stains nuclei this color, which is the color DAPI fluoresces [["floor-ess-is”] when bound to DNA. “Luxol Fast” and Perls’ stains of this color are used to detect demyelination and the presence of iron, respectively.
Demyelinating diseases occur when myelin sheaths on the axons of these cells are damaged. The dendrites of these cells receive electrical impulses.
Name this king of Sweden who disguises himself as Gangleri and questions the three lords High, Just-As-High, and Third in the first part of the Prose Edda.
High, Just-As-High, and Third are pseudonyms employed by this one-eyed Norse god, the All-Father of the Norse Pantheon.
The second part of the Prose Edda, the Skaldskaparmal, is named after these professional verse writers. Odin stole a mead named for these people from Suttung.
